awd_titl_txt: Contrast-enhanced MicroCT-based Analysis of Human Atheroma Biomechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
More than half of the 500,000 deaths each year in the U.S. caused by what is called "acute coronary syndrome" result from the rupture of the thin fibrous cap that covers an "atheroma", a site where the artery is "hardened."  The rupture of an atheroma cap is a very complex phenomenon governed by many factors beyond its thickness. Recent finite element studies have found that the maximal stresses in thin caps are typically far less than the widely accepted threshold for tissue rupture, revealing that cap thickness is not the only or even the most important criterion. The critical rupture stress threshold was established many years ago using 2D finite element modeling in which the vessel wall layers were considered homogeneous, isotropic and elastic, while in reality, the tissue composition in blood vessels, particularly in atheromas is non-homogeneous, non-isotropic and hyperelastic. The overall goal of this research is to investigate the contribution of cap morphology, tissue heterogeneity, and blood flow dynamics on the biomechanics of cap rupture in human coronary vessels. This research will form the basis for developing new strategies for imaging, preventing and possibly reverting changes in tissue composition that transform a stable plaque into one vulnerable to rupture.  The educational component of this effort integrates a multidisciplinary education plan on cardiovascular biomechanics, advanced 3D imaging, and multiscale finite-element modeling. The PIs will  provide training to undergraduate students (through academic year and summer research opportunities) and graduate students (PhD research) and offer internships for underrepresented high-school students to work in the laboratory. 

This research will advance the field of cardiovascular biomechanics by increasing our understanding of vulnerable plaque rupture as well as providing an alternative paradigm for vulnerable plaque risk. To this end, the PIs will use laboratory physical models, contrast-enhanced high-resolution microCT imaging, fluid-solid interaction numerical models with tissue specific properties and mechanical testing in human coronary vessels with atheromas. A novel contrast-enhanced microCT-based finite element modeling approach with realistic vessel wall layers morphology and pixel-based tissue composition will provide a more accurate 3D spatial distribution of stresses and a revised analysis of the critical threshold for atheroma cap rupture. This approach will also be used to investigate the actual mechanism of initiation of the cap rupture. In general, contrast-enhanced high-resolution microCT imaging and advanced numerical modeling are expected to yield mechanistic insights of the composition-structure-function relationship in both stable and vulnerable atheromas in human coronary vessels.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Acute coronary syndrome events are generally due to the asymptomatic rupture of the thin fibrous cap overlying the lipid core of an atheroma lesion, followed by the formation of an occluding thrombus and myocardial infarction. For long time, it has been believed that the main determinant of plaque vulnerability is the cap thickness (<65µm thick). However, recent clinical studies have shown that cap thickness alone is not able to fully predict atherosclerotic plaque rupture. Recent data from our laboratory suggest that there are at least two other key factors influencing the vulnerability of an atheroma, the presence of microcalcifications (μCalcs) in the cap, and the heterogeneity of the cap tissue. Analysis of a large number of human atheroma samples, have shown that at least 35% of them contained µCalcs (~5-50µm size) in their caps. The presence of microcalcifications (µCalcs) in fibrous caps, which behave as local stress concentrators, increase the local tissue stress by a factor 2 to 7, surpassing the ultimate stress threshold for cap tissue rupture in caps, and transforming stable atheroma into lesions vulnerable to rupture. Another factor leading to local stress concentration is an increased heterogeneity of the atheroma tissue and its mechanical properties.

In this study, we developed and tested a contrast-enhanced microCT (CEμCT) approach that provides excellent 3D morphology of the atheroma and its tissue composition. Such approach was used to create Fluid-Structure Interaction (FSI) models with tissue specific properties for a revised analysis of the critical rupture threshold in human atheroma. Those advances in cardiovascular imaging and biomechanics allowed us to pursue the following major goals: (1) to determine the effect of inhomogeneous material properties and accurate atheroma morphology on the stress-strain behavior and rupture threshold of atheroma. (2) To determine the effect of µCalc(s) on the mechanical behavior of the vessel wall and the ultimate stress (rupture threshold) of human coronary atheroma. (3) To investigate the rupture mechanism of fibrous caps with and without µCalc(s). (4) To develop a multidisciplinary program on Cardiovascular Biomechanics and Biomedical Imaging for undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in STEM and Biomedical Engineering. To achieve these goals, we use laboratory physical models, contrast-enhanced microCT imaging, FSI numerical simulations, experimental cardiovascular mechanical testing on human coronary atheroma, summer science camp on imaging and numerical modeling for undergraduates, and research mentoring opportunities.

Among the key outcomes of this study, we have found that several morphology and tissue composition traits, including the remodeling index (i.e. stenosis), cap thickness and core stiffness are significant contributors to the spatial map stress distribution in the blood vessel. We have also determined that the location of plaque rupture is modulated by changes on the heterogeneity of the tissue properties in the atheroma cap, suggesting that a heterogeneous spatial distribution of tissue properties is an important determinant of the maximal stress, strain and plaque rupture in the atheroma. More importantly, microcalcifications have a multiplicative effect on the maximal stresses produced in the cap. This synergistic effect compounds the rupture risk in plaques with low remodeling index, soft lipid cores and thin caps, producing an additional 2.5-fold increase in atheroma vulnerability. It was thus shown that human coronary atheroma that had a stable phenotype, can be transformed into vulnerable plaques under the presence of a μCalc in its cap. Both, cap thickness and μCalcs are the two most influential factors of mechanical rupture risk. These findings provide supporting evidence that high risk lesions are non-obstructive plaques with soft cores and a thin cap with μCalcs. However, stable plaques may still rupture in the presence of μCalcs. These findings support previous numerical and analytical studies suggesting that μCalcs located within the atheroma cap may be responsible for significantly increasing the risk of cap rupture that precedes myocardial infarction and sudden death. Our summer science camp and research opportunities for undergraduates program has a significant educational impact on the engineering and science students at the City College of New York (CCNY) in a number of different ways. First, by increasing the research possibilities for undergraduates, graduate students and collaboration with other faculty. Second, by maintaining the courses with experimental and imaging hands-on lab modules. Third, the proposed cardiovascular and microCT imaging approaches have strengthen the imaging emphasis on our campus, which allow us to better prepare CCNY students for industry and graduate studies.

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2023
Modified by: Luis Cardoso
